DOC.HEAD: Bradley Admits No Wrong, But Uses Own Money to Settle Ethics Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Tom Bradley admitted no wrongdoing but agreed to spend $20,000 of his own money to settle an ethics lawsuit charging he unlawfully failed to disclose personal financial holdings, a judge said. The agreement disclosed Thursday settles a civil lawsuit filed Sept. 13 by City Attorney James K. Hahn. It charged Bradley with failing to report personal financial holdings, amounting to roughly $160,000, on six occasions. Typically, politicians have been allowed to use campaign funds to settle such lawsuits, said Superior Court Judge Robert I. Weil, who called the Bradley deal ``unique and extraordinary.'' Nevertheless, Weil said Thursday that Bradley's errors were acts of negligence, not done with criminal or willful intent. The settlement, Weil added, ``does not constitute an admission of liability.'' Bradley said in a statement: ``Though none of my mistakes was intentional, I have repeatedly taken public responsibility for the inadvertent errors. ``Therefore, I chose the highly unusual step of resolving this manner by paying the settlement from my own resources. The decision to use my personal funds was mine and mine alone.'' Hahn, however, characterized Bradley's violations as ``significant'' and said the $20,000 Bradley paid personally to settle the case was unprecedented. ``The fact that he is the mayor, the chief executive officer of the entire municipal corporation of Los Angeles, I think, holds him to a high degree of requirement to fill out these statements of economic interest accurately every year,'' Hahn said. The lawsuit was filed after the mayor revealed he had made more than 100 errors and omissions in his statements of economic interest from 1984 to 1988. At least $222,000 in investments and income weren't reported; Hahn sued over $160,000 of it. The agreement settles only one aspect of Bradley's crisis over ethics and finances. A federal grand jury is investigating the mayor's business ties to eight banks, savings and loans associations and brokerage firms for possible insider stock trading or violations of federal laws aimed at political corruption.
